Say out loud what you need to hear. Others will need to hear it too.

Preparing to present at a conference maybe and even that slight touch makes me ache for the academic I should have been. It hurts. It hurts that I was forced out and it hurts that I know my contributions will always be taken less seriously because I don't have the "credentials".

I'm hoping for a future in which the academy as we know it is unrecognizable. Where contributions are valued on their merit rather than on their source. And I'm hoping for a future where people like us get to contribute, and where our contributions are valued.

And for whatever it's worth, I'm with you. I'm dreaming a radical dream where anyone can contribute to human understanding, regardless of their "credentials". I'm dreaming of a world in which people are valued for who they are, rather than for who they aren't.

You deserve a world where you are valued, not for your ability to contort yourself into a carbon copy of what "success" looks like, but for your effort and brilliance and nuance and understanding. You deserve a world where *you* are valued, because *you* are valuable.

So here's to those who were forced out, or who never even got their chance. You are worth so much more than the system has told you. You deserve radical self love + self respect. You deserve to know that the system failed you, that it's not your fault, that you deserve better.

I try not to think about the amount of human knowledge and culture and science that has been lost because of the hegemony of academia. About the legions of brilliant, dedicated people who have been turned away, or never gotten an opportunity at all.

And honestly, it's tragic, and it's rage inducing, that the academic system would rather pretend it is based on merit than dare to adjust itself to allow for nuanced perspective. So many people who have so much to offer have been failed by this system, and will continue to be.

The system fails those who aren't affluent, who aren't white, who aren't abled, who aren't cishet, who aren't neurotypical, who aren't singularly focused on academia. It especially fails those who are multiply marginalized.

So let me tell you, here, that if you tried genuinely, if you did all you could, and still "failed", the system failed you, not the other way around. The system fails so, so many people, and it persists by convincing us that we failed the system.

I think this silence has a lot to do with shame. There's a pervasive belief that being forced out of academia is a personal failure, indicative of poor intelligence or lack of work ethic or lack of initiative. I, for one, try to fight that shame, both in myself and others.
There's mourning to be done when leaving academia, which I see talked about often. What I don't see talked about nearly enough is the intense mourning of being forced out of academia.

So for those who have been rejected or abandoned by those systems - I see you. I see your worth, and it is so much more than what you've been told.
Evaluating someone based on academic or industry achievements is evaluating them on a system arbitrarily skewed towards rewarding affluence, whiteness, neurotypicality, physical ability and more.
So here's a reminder that achievements such as these don't correlate to intelligence, work ethic, moral value, or overall worth.

It's that season again where people announce their new jobs and matches so here's a reminder; these programs by design obstruct marginalized people from accessing their achievements. Yes, it takes hard work to achieve these things. But it also takes luck of the draw.

Rejecting the need to sort others into labels or categories and instead accepting self-identification is a radical kind of freedom and a radical kind of love for the sheer diversity and range of human beings.

Attempting to adhere to rigid definitions will cause one thing - constant arguing about who is "correct" in their definition of a term. This is ironic, as each individual is likely correct in their own definition as it applies to them, and no universal definition can be reached.

Attempts at universal, rigid definitions will always fail, because humans create as many exceptions to the rules as there are individuals, and because the meanings of terms change throughout time, space and community.

So what are the advantages of self-identification? Frankly, self-identification is the only system that works without exceptions to include everyone in a group. Without self-identification, any universal, rigid definition is going to exclude *someone* who belongs to a group.

This means that an individual's definition of themself and their labels doesn't apply to anyone else automatically. They are defining a term as it relates to them personally, not defining any term universally.

It is reliant on one core tenet - self definition. It is crucial to accept that one definition of a term will never apply to everyone, and through the process of self-identification, one's individual definition of a term is just that - individual.
Self-identification is widely practiced in the trans and disabled communities, and I would argue it should be practiced in the cisqueer community as well.

This concept seems deceptively simple at first, but its ramifications are profound. If you believe in self-identification, you reject the idea that labels must be bestowed on someone by external or societal forces. You leave one's identity purely in their own hands.

Self-identification is just what it says it is. It means that each individual can identify themselves as belonging to a category or not. This means that only the individual can determine whether or not they belong to a community.

The concept of self-identification is integral to the trans community. It is the only way to successfully support trans people. But many cisqueer people haven't given the concept of self-identification as much thought. I believe it's integral to the larger queer community also.

Care about living trans people. Protect us. Defend us. Value us.

The rest of this thread will be ways you can help.
Speak up. Mount protests, get press attention and write about these bills. Whatever platform you have, *use it*. Every bit counts. You can follow @StepUp4Trans to keep educated and updated on these bills.

The only thing standing in the way of these bills is us. It's long past time we do something to protect vulnerable kids. It's literally life or death. Of children. Yet people look away. Will you look away? Or will you do something?

These bills will kill. These bills are already killing just by being proposed. What are you doing about it? Are you looking away?

So pay attention to who is celebrated for their traits and who is accused of having an "unfair advantage". It has much more to do with cultural bias than with the concept of "fairness in sport".

"Fairness in sport" is an oxymoron. Sport isn't designed to be fair, it's designed to be competitive. It's designed to give advantage to specific traits. It's designed to give individuals advantage over others. "Fairness in sport" is a shield for bigotry, expertly used to exclude

This week, with the saga of Kamila Valieva and Sha'Carri Richardson, we have seen how the perception of what is fair in sports is highly biased. Who decides who is "fair" in sports decides who is allowed to play, to be seen, and, from a cultural standpoint: who is allowed.

I'll use my favorite example, Michael Phelps. He is widely considered one of the greatest swimmers in history. Due to a genetic quirk, his lungs have twice the capacity of the average person's. Is that fair? Who gets to decide if that's fair? Who gets that power?
Because who we decide is playing fair is who we decide gets to compete. Who you decide isn't playing fair is who you are consciously deciding to exclude.

Moreover, who you decide is "playing fair" says a lot about you and your values.
Is someone who is naturally above average height "playing fair"?
Is someone who naturally has higher muscle mass "playing fair"?
Is someone who is transgender "playing fair"?
Continuing to prioritize the myth of "fairness in sport" over protecting the vulnerable tells me one thing - it's not about fairness to you.

Here are some facts. Sports aren't fair. Sports will never be fair. Your ability to succeed at a specific sport is dependent on a genetic lottery, access to training opportunities, equipment, and just plain luck. Sure it also takes a lot of work, but so does any accomplishment.
I'm so tired of the hero-worshipping of sports in popular culture. I'm so tired of the attitude that preserving the myth of "fairness in sport" is more important than preventing tangible harm.

Until we live in a world where human life is valued above profit, we aren't likely to see investments into public health and the infrastructure that maintains it, even as it becomes more and more critical.
@howardtayler It feels very prepper ish, but frankly, after seeing the systemic response to COVID, I don't blame anyone for taking a prepper-ish attitude towards climate change.

In a near future, where climate change increases both rainfall in many regions and flooding itself, diseases like cholera may very well return to Europe and North America... We may not have the luxury of sanitation being such an invisible issue for long.

Many old sewage systems operate on a "combined flow" model, meaning that when flooding or high water volume overload the system, it responds by dumping combined storm water and sewage into nearby water bodies.
These antiquated systems are often insufficient for our current populations, let alone resilient enough to handle increased water flow due to climate change.

Remember that thread I did on cholera? You know, the disease so deadly that it inspired modern plumbing and sanitation? A lot of sewage systems haven't been updated *since the 1800s* when they were first implemented.
https://t.co/3MaSYFwCM9
@ted_fielding Yes, absolutely. A lot of them also work in a way that when there's flooding, sewage and storm water will flow together into nearby water bodies.

The sewer system DOES run a deficit which is why sewer systems in most major cities in the US are 50+ years old, with many in the east being as much as 100+ years old. Yes, that means many have *never been replaced, ever*. 
Invest in infrastructure. https://t.co/e9zgBh7m82

@hexavqior Absolutely; I discuss this more in detail further down in the thread!

Gender based oppression is a hugely wide scope that impacts every group slightly differently and with different relative privilege. The complexity of these matters is *important*, and understanding and respecting relative privilege is necessary to practice intersectional feminism

Intersectional feminism becomes even more complex, fighting for anyone for whom the intersection of gender and other discriminatory factors is relevant. This includes many cis men, for example, cis men of color, disabled cis men, queer cis men, and more.
Feminism is fundamentally about fighting for the equality of all who face gender-based oppression. This means that feminism absolutely includes cis women, trans women, and trans men in its purview.

So for summary, the gender only privilege scale goes like this, with "greater" indicating greater privilege.

Transfemmes < transmascs < cis women < cis men

In reality, this scale becomes much more complex due to intersectionality and intersections of discrimination.

Being relatively privileged is not the same as being privileged. Transmascs are relatively privileged over transfemmes. But transmisia still means that all trans people are discriminated against. Transmascs are not privileged relative to cis people, including cis women.

Discussing the particular aspects of transandromisia is important! Critical, even, especially as most of these conversations are silenced due to transmas erasure.
But if you are only interested in discussing transandromisia as an attack against transfemmes, that's transmisogyny.

It is absolutely possible for transmascs to be transmisogynistic due to their relative privilege over transfemmes. It is critical that we recognize this, and fight it internally, in order to be in solidarity with our sisters and our community at large.

This is the important bit; transandromisia (the discrimination of transmascs) is not the same as transmisogyny (the discrimination of transfemmes). Transandromisia is also not transfemmes fault. Transfemmes do not have systemic power over transmascs by virtue of being transfemme.

Specific discrimination of transmascs due to intersections of transphobia and misogyny absolutely occur. It is a byproduct of transmasculine erasure that there are few good terms to use to discuss this phenomena. Transmasculine erasure also makes it difficult to discuss.

I talk about this because it's important for people to realize just how hostile medicine is to trans people, and just how inaccessible medically necessary treatments are. I'm white, educated, relatively affluent. I have insurance. I'm the best case scenario. And I am devastated.

I am a trans man with endometriosis and anxiety, depression, PTSD and EDS that are exacerbated by my estrogen levels. This hysto is medically necessary, but it has consistently been treated as a luxury by transphobic insurance providers.
I was told I could try again in July. I'm moving to another state in May, where none of this work will transfer and I will need to start this process over from scratch.

They wouldn't fix it fast enough, so my surgery slot was given away. Today, the sixth time, there was no room for me on the patient list. I started this process in August of 2020 and here I am, in January of 2022, with nothing whatsoever to show for it.
So I waited. The fifth time, my insurance issued my policy in my deadname, despite that not being my legal name for over a year and having had the documentation of that change for over a year.
So I proved I'd socially transitioned for a year and a half. The fourth time, the hospital was too full with COVID patients to take me.
So I waited until I'd been on HRT for a year. The third time, I was told I needed to have been "socially transitioned" for at least a year and a half.

So I got another letter of recommendation. The second time, I was rejected 24 hours before my surgery bc insurance said I needed to be on HRT for at least a year before getting a hysto, which they hadn't mentioned the first time.

It's been over a year now.
The first time, I got two letters of recommendation and got diagnosed with gender identity disorder. I was rejected 24 hours before my surgery bc my insurance said the doctor who diagnosed me with GID wasn't a legitimate person to get a letter from.

"Frustration" is too small a word. "Anger" has more energy than I'm currently able to muster. "Exhaustion" is probably closest.
I just want to be able to exist in peace. I jumped through all the hoops put in place. I did everything they required of me, and it didn't matter.

Update; just heard I cannot be scheduled for February, meaning my surgery is postponed for a 6th time and I'll have to start the process entirely over in a new city and a new state, relearning all the regulations. I'm so tired. I feel like I have nothing left to give. https://t.co/vdEtROofFK
Together, we can make a safer world for trans youth. Together, we can fight these hateful, unnecessary bills. Together, we can make a difference. Together, we can #StepUpForTransKids.
If you are able and would like to support my organization's work, please consider donating to our gofundme for operational costs, here: https://t.co/99TBML6eBt

You can also follow @StepUp4Trans for daily updates and news about hateful legislation in the United States. 
These representatives think they can eliminate trans people without anyone noticing, but we MUST prove them wrong. Please take notice. Please speak up.

My nonprofit, the Trans Formations Project, has a website where we track all anti-trans legislation in the United States, tell you exactly which representatives to contact, and provide contact information for those representatives, all in the same place. 
https://t.co/7hIQH7Hpqa

All of these hateful bills are at the state level, meaning that state representatives are those to contact. If you live in one of the states marked in red, YOUR state is considering anti-trans legislation RIGHT NOW. https://t.co/Bn2mwgOxio

These efforts have coalesced into a small, volunteer run nonprofit that is dedicated to tracking and educating about this crisis. Because throughout all the attacks on trans youth, we are not helpless, we just need help. Allies, YOU can be the difference here.

Last year I realized that almost no one was tracking these bills or drawing sufficient attention to them. So I started tracking them myself, on this twitter account. Soon, people wanted to help me. So many trans people felt that no one else cared, and wanted to make an impact.

This is the second year of bills like these, and the second year of every trans person I know yelling for someone, anyone to care. Last year, 20 of these bills PASSED INTO LAW. Yet no one is panicking but trans people. Where are the allies? Where are the reasonable people?

Living, breathing trans people are becoming political pawns in a culture war, and almost no one is coming to our aid. Make no mistake, trans people are suffering. Trans people are dying. Kids are dying. And these bills, if passed, will have a death toll.
These outcomes are specifically improved when it comes to suicide rates, which are catastrophically high in the trans community. These laws, if passed, will kill trans youth. https://t.co/O62IzoB1iE

Many other bills seek to ban trans-affirming medical care, therapies or even trans-positive messaging from being applied to minors, despite all reputable research showing that early intervention for trans children leads to markedly improved outcomes.
https://t.co/ffC1QAnywZ
It is not an exaggeration to say that these bills, created from fearmongering about trans youth, especially trans women, will be catastrophically harmful to youth, and particularly girls, as a whole.

Some of these bills specify that "biological sex" must be determined based on genitalia. Some specify that examinations of genitalia must be performed by a doctor, but most do not. If this were to pass into law, how are genital examinations of children by schools to be conducted?
Even worse, many of these laws only apply these restrictions to girls' athletics, placing a cost barrier only on women and girls' participation in school sports.

Some of these bills specify that "biological sex" must be determined by chromosomes or hormonal levels. That would require costly doctors appointments, functionally placing an affluence limit on who can participate in school athletics.

Even the bills that seem "mild", such as the bills that ban trans girls from playing girls sports, have incredibly dark implications. If sports are to be segregated by "biological sex", how is "biological sex" to be determined?

There are bills that seek to ban all trans-affirming medical care, including puberty blockers, for minors, or even some that ban this care up to age 21. 
A prior thread of mine on puberty blockers can be found here: https://t.co/69WyKsjOF2

These bills are heinous, ranging from sports bills to bills that seek to make gender affirming social changes (such as preferred names or pronouns) classified as child abuse. There are bills that would mandate outing trans children to their parents.
It's the 1st of February, and already there are more than 75 bills being considered that would limit trans rights in the US.

If you live in the United States, there are more than 75 anti-trans laws that are currently being considered, and it's only January. That's more than two hateful laws per state. I urge you to please go to https://t.co/7hIQH7Hpqa to learn about bills in your state and reach out.

The cultural war on trans rights is happening all around us, and it is going largely unnoticed by the general population. I beg you to stand up and to do something now, before it's too late. Before they come for someone else. Before trans people have to suffer any more.
So I urge you to make the connection - in the rise of fascism, they came for queer people early. They came for trans people early. And I urge you to look around at the current state of the world.

But what's often missing from that narrative is this story - of Magnus Hirschfield, and of the Institute of Sexual Sciences, and of the unfathomable amount of knowledge and lives destroyed in prejudice nearly a decade before war broke out.

One aspect that is repeated, over and over again when it comes to Holocaust stories, is that we must remain vigilant against the rise of fascism, and never, ever allow such atrocities to happen again.

Upon liberation of camps, when other prisoners were freed, queer prisoners were merely transported to different prisons. After all, they were still committing what were considered illegal and deviant acts.

Lesbians (and afab trans people) were labeled as "antisocial" and labeled with black triangles. Queer prisoners of concentration camps were considered the lowest of the low, being treated notably worse by guards and by other prisoners.

This would set the tone for the future, when queer people were notoriously hunted down as undesireables and placed in concentration camps. Gay men (and amab trans people) were famously labeled with pink triangles. 
I wrote about the pink triangle here: https://t.co/E8iSDhjn15

What is also notable, however, is what the students did not burn. They did not burn patient's medical records, but instead used them to hunt down previous patients of the Institute for persecution under the law.

Nearly 20,000 volumes, many of which could be found nowhere else, were burned. The amount of knowledge of queerness, gender equality, tolerance and trans medical care that was lost can never be fully known.

On that date, fascist students overran the Institute, ransacking the library. You've almost certainly seen this image before, although without its specific circumstances. The first "Nazi Book Burning", nearly a decade before WWII, was of the Institute for Sexual Sciences' library https://t.co/49JHrWagvB
There were arguments that the Institute was "corrupting youth into unclean lifestyles" and that Hirschfield was a "morally corrupt Jew". These arguments boiled over on May 6th, 1933.

The Institute eventually went on to have over 40 full time employees interested in research and advocacy for queer and intersex individuals who otherwise had nowhere to turn. But from the beginning, the Institute had been controversial.
The Institute was also the first place to allow for trans-affirming medical care, including HRT and trans affirming surgeries. https://t.co/Cpa29OfEgc

Particularly revolutionary was the Institute's early advances in transgender affirming care. The Institute had a lawyer to help people change their names, issued certification papers allowing trans people to legally cross dress, and went out of their way to hire trans people. https://t.co/4KghKQonVJ

The Institute soon became the world hub of the newly emergent field of "sexology". It was equal parts research institution and political powerhouse - it advocated for and produced research relating to queer rights, access to contraception, women's equality and more.
In 1928 he founded the World League for Sexual Reform, an organization that argued for the decriminalization of homosexuality, the rights of women, contraceptive rights and more.

Both the film and the institute faced immediate criticism. The film was banned by German officials within a year. In 1920, Hirschfield, an openly gay, socialist and Jewish man, was attacked and seriously injured. The attacks and threats were nonstop from this point in his career.
In 1919, the same year he founded the Institute, Hirschfield participated in the making of a film, called, "Different from the Others", which argued against criminalization of homosexuality.
1914 saw Hirschfield publish, "Homosexuality in Men and Women", which pioneered the statistical surveying methods later utilized extensively by Alfred Kinsey.

In 1899, Hirschfield established the "Yearbook of Intermediate Sexual Types", the first journal in the world on sexuality and gender variance studies. It was regularly published until 1923. In 1910 he published the first scientific study on cross dressing, "The Transvestites". https://t.co/EhFGGgyjGY
The Scientific-Humanitarian Committee's main objective was to abolish Paragraph 175 of the German Imperial Penal Code, the German sodomy law, which criminalized consensual sex between men.

He believed these "sexual intermediaries" could manifest as intersex conditions, marginalized sexualities, or "transvestism".
In 1897, Hirschfield helped to found the Scientific-Humanitarian Committee. This was the world's first gay rights organization.

Hirschfield believed in "sexual intermediaries", a theory that believed there were many variations of sexuality naturally found within human populations. At this time, "sexuality" encompassed both sexuality as we think of it today, and gender. https://t.co/3Rn7rfRnDf

In 1919, queer people were generally regarded as immoral, depraved people who went against traditional (Christian) values. Hirschfield passionately argued against this, stating that these "values" limited our understanding of human variation and sexuality.

This institute, the Institut für Sexualwissenschaft, was founded by the famous Magnus Hirschfield, a doctor and early queer rights pioneer. Hirschfield held the then-radical opinion that sexuality was innate rather than a moral deviancy or mental illness. https://t.co/mHjlsD2p0Z

This is the story of the Institute of Sexual Sciences, the first institution dedicated to studying gender and sexuality. It was founded, not in 2019, but in 1919, and not in the United States, but in Berlin, Germany.

In a just world, where the sharing of technology and science was done with egalitarianism, this would not be the case. In a just world, where lives and a reduction of suffering mattered more than manufactured scarcity, this would not be the case.

Cholera pandemics are now relegated to only the poorest and most exploited nations, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. This disease of the poor has become a disease of the global poor. https://t.co/H8oYxBF4wc

Cholera is still ongoing, and our fight against it, now armed with the knowledge of sanitation, is still ongoing. We are currently in the midst of the seventh cholera pandemic. https://t.co/CfcgO48Ru0

Finally, after presenting his evidence down to the exact household where the cholera took root, city officials allowed Dr. Snow to shut down the Broad Street Pump.
The deaths almost immediately stopped. But cholera was far from done.

The Broad Street Pump, now famous, had been utilized by residents of this district, and others outside who sought the water out, liking the taste of the Broad Street water specifically. Dr. Snow interviewed residents about cholera deaths, where they got their water, and more.

During the third cholera pandemic, Dr. John Snow meticulously recorded cholera deaths in one of the hardest-hit neighborhoods in London. And, like a vision, they all centered on one singular water pump utilized by residents of the city. https://t.co/ngLl4rf8Cu

With the best of intentions, a lack of knowledge of this new disease had led to resources being utilized in the worst way possible. A scientific body unwilling to consider new ideas ignored the previous findings of one Dr. John Snow, who had a theory that cholera was waterborne.

Catastrophically, London had invested in a huge public infrastructure project making it so that public waste left in the streets would be drained efficiently into the River Thames, efficiently polluting the water supply. According to miasma theory, this was sound practice.
Miasma theory was the idea that disease was caused by bad smells - particularly those of rotting corpses, human or animal waste, or spoiled foods. It was so very close to the truth in many ways.

This is the part of the story where doctor John Snow, the so called father of epidemiology, comes in, and humans get an edge against cholera. In London, the general scientific consensus at the time was focused on miasma theory.

But cholera's impacts didn't end there. The third cholera pandemic swept through the world in the 1850s, bringing hundreds of thousands of deaths in its wake. Here it was nicknamed the "blue death". https://t.co/Ljs9w43p8n

In France, cholera tensions against the aristocracy were so intense that they were instrumental in the buildup to the 1832 June Rebellion (the inspiration for Les Mis) against the aristocracy. https://t.co/aVynEeiHhf
Street riots took hold in England as well. There, people accused doctors of manufacturing cholera deaths in order to steal bodies for medical students to experiment on.
The riot only stopped when the Czar himself intervened, appearing in the main square and calling for protestors to kneel in deference to him. https://t.co/SngjAXH46I

The Russian poor saw quarantines and other measures taken against cholera as a means through which the upper classes were oppressing the poor. They called for the death of all doctors in the city, claiming they had poisoned the wells of the poor.

In 1830-1832, all hell broke loose. Violence rose against the rich, against the classed gentry, against doctors, against patients, against foreigners.
In Russia, protestors specifically organized against measures taken to slow the spread of cholera.

Particularly in Europe, rumors spread. There were those who accused the government of creating the disease to rid their cities of the urban poor. There were outcries against this "Oriental" disease. The press often contributed, with op-eds spurring on these vitriolic claims.

Germ theory hadn't caught on yet. The importance of sanitation was not understood.
In the absence of scientific explanations, paranoia blossomed.

Some of you may have heard much of this story before. But I want to talk about something rarely discussed in the conversation around cholera; cholera riots.
In many places, it was obvious that more poor people were dying of cholera than rich people.
Eventually, however, the first pandemic subsided. The second spread even further, especially to Europe and the Americas. https://t.co/wt1fp52mL5

The first cholera pandemic infected much of the middle east, southeast Asia and central Eurasia. It killed with devastating swiftness. This new disease was like nothing seen before. https://t.co/ikLMLOXqFz
Cholera is a disease of extremes; harmless only within the very conditions that would prevent it, devastatingly deadly without them.

Cholera is completely curable, as it kills through dehydration. If someone afflicted with cholera is given oral rehydration solutions (or even enough uncontaminated water, in many cases), they will almost certainly survive.

Cholera is a very interesting illness. In most people, it causes no effects whatsoever. But in about 1/10th of people infected, it causes the body to lose fluids at such a rate that people can die within a day, blue with dehydration. https://t.co/ec9dWUD0ua

For two years, monsoons struck the Ganges River Delta region of India so strongly that the entire region became swampy marshland. There was no possible way to avoid contaminated water, because all water was mixing constantly.
And here, in 1817, the first cholera outbreak began.

This Tambora eruption was so powerful that it clouded much of Europe and North America in "a year without a summer", caused widespread famines and sickness, and made it snow in August.
In southern Asia, it strengthened the monsoon.

Cholera is particularly interesting because it is a disease that emerged very suddenly. Cholera (of the highly infectious variety) didn't evolve until the 1800s. Specifically, it broke out in 1817, two years after the Tambora volcanic eruption that caused acute climactic change.

Cholera, as many of you likely know, is a bacterial illness spread by fecal-oral routes due to contaminated food or drinking water. It almost universally exists where sanitation infrastructure is low or nonexistent.

In year three of the pandemic, I see many people mourning not only death around us, but a loss of public trust in institutions, spread of misinformation, and governmental instability. For today, I want to talk about something else. I want to talk about cholera. 🧵

Pepper (like ground pepper) is actually a stonefruit and the seed itself is spicy to discourage animals from biting directly into it and killing the seed, instead encouraging animals to swallow the seed whole in order to spread it. Then humans invented pepper grinders.
Garlic, onions, and other pungent roots evolved their tastes specifically to taste bad to animals so that the plants can keep their stores of nutrition safe underground through the winter.

Like, capsaicin (the chemical in spicy peppers that makes them spicy) can't be tasted by birds, only mammals. Spicy peppers evolved this specifically to discourage predation by mammals (who can't distribute seeds very far) and to instead selectively encourage predation by birds.

One of my favorite facts about plant evolution is that most plants we use as spices evolved their particular tastes specifically as a *deterrent* to predation. And then, like usual, humans ruined everything.

Self determination is not a failure of external validation - it is a rejection of it. Making the conscious choice to determine yourself rather than accept the circumstances dictated to you is radical self love in its purest form.

So much of the derision and mockery of trans people is mockery of self determination, and this is why. Transphobes are so deeply entrenched in the belief that external validation is truth that they interpret anything else as failure rather than a different way of being.

And this is where it comes down, as it always does, to the issue of autonomy and self determination. Trans people's self determination is incredibly threatening to a group that is so deeply invested in external validation to the point of external definition.

And this reveals a lot about the underlying tenets of their philosophy. It has no room for individual experience or self-determination. Rather, it enforces that all identifiers must be impressed on someone by outside forces, rather than defined by the individual.

For instance, on the recent Dr. Phil segment of infamy, a nonbinary person was asked to define a woman, to which they replied that they couldn't define the experience of womanhood for everyone, as it is unique. This was treated as a *failure* to define what a woman is by TERFs.

One thing that transphobes have in common is that they are certain that they can define another's experience for them, and they're so insistent on this that a refusal to define someone else is taken as a *failure* to define them.

It can cause existential dread, but we must remember that our stories have power. They have power to change human perception, and guide human action. Stories have saved us many times before, and although the world doesn't owe us an ending with meaning, we can always make one.

But the world, the universe, doesn't play by the same rules as our stories do. There is no miraculous escape, no guarantee of an ending that matters. And I think in the pandemic, and with climate changes looming, many people are grappling with this for the first time.

Stories are an incredible adaptation that allow for human empathy and innovation to reach new heights. However, there is danger in making every struggle into a story. The major danger is that we expect them to end satisfactorily, even if we don't realize this consciously.

Whether this meaning be a moral, or growth of a character, or a resolution to the journey, or a the problem being solved, one thing the stories we tell ourselves almost universally have in common is that they resolve in a way that provides meaning to the story itself.

Humans conceptualize and understand the world through stories. These stories, universally, have similar themes and structures. Stories are the true universal language of all humans, and one thing almost all the stories have in common is that they all end with meaning.
I think something a lot of people are grappling with for the first time is this: the world doesn't owe us a satisfactory ending.

Will I ever be financially stable enough after paying for transition to even consider adopting children?
I imagine this experience is not at all uncommon for trans people. Many of us are unable to have biological children.

I had written off parenthood because I'd thought my only option was dreaded motherhood. Now that I am transitioning, I worry constantly that the world will be too hostile to allow me to pursue fatherhood. Will adoption services, already bigoted, ever even consider me?

I've been thinking a lot about parenthood recently. Before transition, I wanted nothing whatsoever to do with parenthood. It turns out that in actuality, I wanted nothing to do with motherhood. The concept of myself as a mother filled me with dysphoria.

You can't outrun yourself. And all the negative external factors pale in comparison to negative internal factors that I had before transition. I can fight back against external negativity, but before transition I was only fighting myself, a battle I was doomed to lose.

For all the negative impacts of transphobia (and there are many), all of it is still worth it to me, because I'm now a person I can love. And I understand, looking at the potential negatives, it's so hard to take that leap of faith and begin transition.

I try to focus on the positive aspects of being trans here, not because negative aspects don't exist, but because I never want to give anyone the impression that transition isn't worth it. It's a personal decision whether or not to transition, but for me it saved my life.

If you'd like to try your hand at practicing allyship (which is an act, not a state of being), I'll add some things you can materially do to support trans people to this thread.

If you do one thing for me, please think on this; what you learn on my account, following me and paying attention; it isn't allyship.
It is learning the groundwork, the 101 theory, that allows you to practice trans allyship. From there you have to act.

Your allyship matters. And your allyship is only valuable if you've already learned the basics, because the vulnerable among us do not have the time or energy to teach you how to help them.
Which is why I'm here. To help you learn the basics so you can go out and do better.

It's critical that you understand that for all the struggles I talk about on this app, there are many more I don't consider worth mentioning. And that is in my experience as an incredibly privileged trans person.
Trans people are not okay. We are not safe. We need help.

Luck that I was able to pursue higher education. Luck that I found a job willing to take on a trans person (for now). Luck that I was able to access transition therapies with minimal restrictions.
It's critical that you understand that I am the lucky trans person.

As you've all gotten to know me and my struggles with transphobia and gender, it's absolutely critical that you realize; I am one of the luckiest ones. And it is that, luck. Luck that I was born middle class. Luck that I was born white.

The reason for this is largely because I am incredibly privileged compared to the majority of trans people. I'm good at explaining things, so I do my best to make this platform a place where clear explanations can be found, because that work is needed.

If you'd like to learn more about queer history, specifically genderqueer history, please consider checking out articles from my series, #NoMoreRevisionistCistory, which I will link below this tweet.

We must remember that there is far more evidence of queerness historically than is being reported. We must remember that because queerness survived through subtlety, "hedging on the side of caution" when interpreting history is hedging on the side of erasing queer history.

When contemplating how historians and others perceive and report on queer history, it's important to identify how the erasure of queer history, and especially of transgender and genderqueer history, benefits a narrative that seeks to claim that queerness is a new phenomenon.

I wrote a thread about this here:
https://t.co/abqra3UJng

Another important factor is that "queerness" has always included not just marginalized sexualities, but gender variance as well. Until extremely recent history (the past 50 years or so), genderqueerness and queerness were considered one and the same, and deeply interrelated.

We have not yet reached a point, even in places largely considered safe and welcoming for queer people, wherein we are willing to admit that queerness is part of the human condition, and as such, is integral and inextricable to all of human history.

However, with what we know about queer history - that nuance was the language - I believe we should do just the opposite. If anything *could* be queer, I would argue that it likely was. Queerness has always been here, just masked in subtlety and suppression.

This allows the opportunity, in nearly every case of queer history, to argue that it is a matter of interpretation. Usually, it's argued that unless something is overtly and obviously queer, it cannot be proven and should be treated as simply odd.
So much queer history is covert and easily overlooked, not just due to suppression, but by design. Subtlety was necessary to survival for most of history.

The information in this thread comes from the excellent book, "Coming Out Under Fire: Gay Men and Women in WWII" by Allen Berube. The third chapter is explicitly devoted to discussions of camp and drag.

An important lesson from this background knowledge is this; queerness does not exempt groups from racism. 
The "hula girl" herself is a racist charicature. Many "camp" shows featured minstrel acts in blackface.
Queer history is not exempt from racist or colonialist history.
The word "camp" itself comes from the locations these performances were played in; camps and outposts.

The distinctive drag and queer style we now know as "camp" can trace many of its origins to these performers; queer performers who added subtle double entendres to their drag performances, creating their own queer culture on a public stage, with much of the public unaware.

GI drag performances were a major part of most soldier shows, which were produced and performed to increase soldier's morale, especially in remote areas. Drag was excused as being acceptable because of the lack of women in many bases and camps.

These "hula girls" were modeled after GI drag performances, which often featured only the materials GIs had on hand for costumes - materials like using plant matter for skirts, coconuts for bras, and fruit as hats.

Using this rough comparison helps me to be patient with waiting for changes to come, and it also helps calm the panic that comes with worrying if "this is it". It helps remind me there is so much more to come. I've still got years of changes to come.

For example, I am 25 years old. But I am 1.5 years into my second (accurate) puberty. A cis person who is 1.5 years into puberty would be around 13-15 years old. 13-15 year olds aren't done with puberty, not even close! There will still be changes for me for years to come!

I see a lot of posts talking about "I didn't expect x years into transition!" and I want to introduce the concept of hormonal years to y'all. Trans people functionally start puberty at a different age than cis people, but it still takes many years for puberty to settle.

So I hope this thread has helped you to be critical of what people mean when they say something is "renewable"... And whether or not our utilization of resources actually fits that criteria.
8% of the US energy supply was provided by "renewables" in 2010. But wait! 53% of that renewable energy was supplied by biomass... Which is largely the burning of wood. https://t.co/iBmRgvISlt

So why does this matter? It matters because how we talk about renewables influences public opinion, policy, and more.
At the rate we're using wood, wood is not renewable. We are using it faster than wood is being created. This is important bc wood is classified as a "renewable".

Technically, substances like oil or coal *are* renewable, just over a very long timescale. They form from organic matter breaking down over millions of years in specific environments. Oil and coal are forming today, just not nearly at the rate at which we are using them.

Another important factor of this calculation is that we must establish a timescale for which "renewability" is to be evaluated on. Does a resource replenish in a day? A year? A century? Millions of years?

One of my favorite examples of this is wood. For wood to be a renewable resource, all the trees in the world need to add more wood content than is felled over a certain period of time. In the current world, wood is not renewable by this definition.
In reality, a resource is truly renewable if it is being used at a lesser rate than it is being replenished. This rules out many resources we widely consider "renewable".

This simple concept has far reaching implications. For instance, something like water is usually cited as renewable, but in certain places, where underground aquifers are being drained faster than they're being refilled by rainfall, that's not the case.
 https://t.co/TUDHrYvjB9

In reality, something being a renewable resource or not has to do with the *rate* we use it at, not an inherent property of a substance itself. For instance, solar energy is renewable not bc the sun is infinite, but bc the sun produces much more solar energy than we use.

I want to talk about the framework we use around the word "renewable". It's a word that gets thrown around a lot, and that is usually thought of as a binary, aka something is either renewable or not. That's not exactly the truth. 🧵

The research for this thread was taken from: Homosexuality; A History (From Ancient Greece to Gay Liberation) by Vern Bullough, although, ironically, he too uses these examples as history a history of sexuality only, and does not discuss their implications for genderqueerness.

This has a few implications in the modern culture and era. Firstly, transness and genderqueerness is far from new. Secondly, the queer community has always included genderqueer individuals. And thirdly, our modern attempts to rigidly define genderqueerness are likely to fail.
Before this, for most of human history, queerness was perceived as being related not to gender *or* sexuality, but to gender *and* sexuality by default.

These examples are far from the only ones, but it is important to acknowledge that the distinction between genderqueerness and sexuality-based queerness is a distinction that has only existed for the last century at most.

Edward Carpenter (1844-1929), an early queer rights activist and writer who collaborated with Havelock Ellis, wrote a book in 1908 called "The Intermediate Sex", in which he argued that queer individuals were suited for leadership bc they combined male and female characteristics.

The french doctor Paul Moreau argued that in addition to other human senses, there was a "genital sense" that could be damaged. He believed that queerness resulted from an inborn defect of the genital sense that caused an intermediate gender between male and female.

In the modern era, we may see this individual as either a bitch lesbian or a trans man. In 1869, no distinction was made, rather, both the individual's attraction and gender were considered related aspects of their queerness.

One of the earliest case studies in queerness was conducted by Carl Westphal, a psychiatrist, in 1869, on a "young woman" who preferred to dress as a boy, play boys games and was only attracted to women.

He specifically describes the "urning" as a female soul trapped in a male body, and the "urningin" as a male soul trapped in a female body. He was a notable queer theorist because he himself was queer and drew from his own experiences to theorize on queer identity.

This third sex, "urning" was the word Ulrichs used to define queer individuals. He believed that the "urning" were neither wholly male or wholly female, but possessed the body of one sex, but the soul of another.

One of the first western queer theorists, Karl Heinrichs Ulrichs (1825-1895), theorized that until a certain point of development, all sexes were the same. Upon differentiation, he wrote, there were actually three sexes, not two; males, females, and a third sex he called "urning"
Voltaire himself theorized that queerness arose from individuals being confused about the exact gender of who they were attracted to, particularly as children, when androgyny is the norm.

Early explanations for the reason behind queerness show this conflation. For instance, many ancient Greek writers theorized that queer people were queer because their souls were neither fully male or fully female.

This is not to say that trans people didn't exist - they absolutely did, we have evidence of trans people going back thousands of years. It's to say that until the early 1900s, "queerness" was considered an attribute that included both sexuality and gender without distinction.

It's taking everything in me not to title the article I'm writing up about phallocentrism and how it plays into both rape culture and transphobia, "The Cult of the Penis; Cutting Off the Head of the One-Eyed Snake"

The cultish cultural attitude that sees penises as sacred objects of great danger, power and authority is antithetical to feminism and especially transfeminism. Phallocentrism is sexist and transphobic.

Penises are not magic. Penises don't have inherent power. Penises are not inherently dangerous. Acting like it's the penis that's dangerous and not the rapist is catastrophically harmful and antifeminist.

The obsession with penises as an object of inherent power and *danger* also harms trans women disproportionately and is a huge factor in transmisogyny and transfeminine fetishization. 
It also harms all people of marginalized genders by firmly entrenching sexism and cissexism.

Placing the causative agent of sexual assault as an object (what were they wearing?) or body part (only penises can commit assault!) rather than a person responsible for their own actions places blame everywhere except where it needs to be placed.
There's a conversation many people aren't ready for that *needs* to be had about the phallocentrism of assuming that the threat of sexual assault comes from possessing a penis and nothing else.

Soldiers would out themselves as a political statement, and veterans seeking to overturn their dishonorable discharges set the stage for a movement of queer rights, particularly a movement to be seen as equal by governmental institutions.

-literally founding the gay bars and other establishments that would house this community. After being outed and dishonorably discharged from military service for being homosexual, many queer individuals found themselves with a community and a sense that they deserved better.

In this way and in others, WWII likely had a massive influence on the origins of the queer liberation movement to follow. WWII provided socialization opportunities for queer people that had not previously existed, beginning a sense of solidarity and community, and in many cases-

This marked a turning point, and the point in which queerness was interpreted as an identity or an aspect of a person, rather than an action. This cultural concept is necessary to understand that queerness is an inherent attribute, and a marker of human diversity.

Prior to this time, laws were constructed that banned the act of sodomy... And cultural attitudes conceptualized sodomy as that - an act. The burgeoning fields of psychology were implemented to try to exclude those of "homosexual personality" from drafts.

I'm reading Allen Bérubé's "Coming Out Under Fire", which is a history of queer American soldiers during WWII and one of the most fascinating things I've stumbled upon so far is that the WWII draft likely influenced the concept of a person being gay, rather than an act.

@less_soft_bird When I've gotten migraines at work I was once accused of being drunk bc my migraine symptoms presented as loss of coordination, slow reaction times and slurred speech. I was nearly fired bc I wasn't believed that this was a migraine.

@less_soft_bird Oh yeah absolutely. I've been regularly denied accomodations for my migraines bc professors and employers thought it was "just a bad headache". I've been told to take some pain meds and come in anyway.

...muscle weakness, numbness, light and sound sensitivity, smell sensitivity, difficulty speaking, depression, anxiety, irritability and more. Migraines are much more than just a bad headache, but the conflation of these terms regularly make people underestimate migraine severity

While migraines are poorly understood, they are very serious. Symptoms can range from head pain, dizziness, body aches, digestive symptoms, nausea, loss of coordination or balance, memory loss, swelling, vision loss or hallucinations, auditory loss or hallucinations...
A migraine isn't just a "really bad headache", it's a complex collection of possible symptoms that can be much more dehabilitating than pain alone.
Please don't conflate the words "migraine" and "headache". The conflation of these makes it extremely difficult for migraine sufferers to be taken seriously.

"I only accept top achieving candidates" = "I only accept those who have had the privileges necessary to be high achieving in a system that discriminates" = "I don't accept minoritized candidates as a rule"
Overwhelmingly, these are people who despite being minoritized, are privileged in other ways. For instance, why academic queer communities are overwhelmingly white and affluent.

"Wanting diverse candidates," without being willing to acknowledge that metrics for evaluating diverse candidates are inherently flawed will give you only a tiny subset of diversity - those who managed to survive a system rigged against them.
In order to actively fight rigged systems, you must be willing to evaluate individuals and their potential by other metrics than those provided by the very system that discriminates against them.
"I just only accept top achieving candidates" is an attitude that, in a system rigged so that minoritized people will fail and be systematically excluded, only serves to continue the status quo.

@jim_devinney Boat checks are definitely helpful, but can't be a replacement for good stewardship on the part of angler's themselves!

Following these basic principles can help keep aquatic environments clean, healthy and enjoyable for generations to come, as well as making sure that our ecosystems are resilient enough to support their unique species and us.
Also for the anglers who may be reading along, avoid using felt-soled waders! Microscopic organisms can hide and survive in the damp interior of the felt and be transferred between water bodies.

If you fish or boat, also make sure that your equipment isn't accidentally transporting water (keep your equipment in good working condition) and dry or clean it thoroughly between using it in different water bodies.

If you fish or boat, you also should make sure no aquatic plants are attached to your gear when you leave a water body. Many aquatic plants can propagate simply through fragments that get caught on equipment.

Basically - don't spread water or organisms around. If you catch aquatic organisms or even scoop water into a container for safekeeping (especially in the cases of fishing live-wells), put it back where it came from!

Secondly, be very careful about transporting water between water bodies (including from a home aquarium!). Many aquatic organisms start their lives as microscopic, free-floating larva, and so even the transfer of seemingly-clean water between water bodies can spread invasives!

Many aquatic invasive species, including plants, started in people's home aquariums as people tried to "release" their pets to the wild. These cause untold harm to other species, and can collapse whole communities of organisms.

There are things YOU can do to prevent aquatic invasive species in your own life! Firstly, NEVER dump unwanted pets, including fish or even plants! Rehome your pets, or, if necessary, have them euthanized before you release them to the wild, where they may cause untold harm.

The best way to deal with the problem of invasive species is to prevent them from being introduced in the first place. With freshwater invasive species, we have unique opportunities for prevention, as these species cannot travel over land to new water bodies by themselves.

Invasive species can disrupt ecosystems dramatically and cause irreparable damage not only to the species that live in a region, but also to the ecosystem services that ecosystems provide. I wrote a thread on the hazards of invasive species here!

@LiManMa16795669 @BLLoversLink Because you've been taught, through societal and individual reactions, to empathize with certain individuals more than others.
These jokes attempt to construe "identifying" as something foreign to the average person, based purely upon their own misunderstanding of what an identity itself is or what that word means.

All of these things are completely commonplace statements. These jokes try to argue that identifying one's gender is outside the realm of normal human experience, which is absurd.
"I identify as a woman" = "I am a woman"
"I identify as a man" = "I am a man"

And the thing is that as soon as you replace those "jokes" with an identity that makes any sense, they just become... Completely normal things.
"I identify as an accountant", "I identify as a student", "I identify as a disabled person", "I identify as a queer person"

The truth about all of those "I identify as an attack helicopter" jokes is that they miss the fundamental reality that identity is something every single human being on earth has. To "identify with" something just means that it describes you as a person.

The truth is that cis people should imagine that their body and the way others treat them doesn't reflect their genuine gender. Without the willingness to understand + dissect this nuance, rather than going with the immediate emotional reaction, cis people's empathy is weaponized

I believe this is one of the major "selling points" of the gender critical movement - they weaponize pure empathy. Most cis people trying to imagine being trans imagine themselves transitioning - and are horrified. That immediate emotional response is weaponized against trans ppl

I want to let that thread stand alone, but I also want to commentate that for trans issues, this is especially crucial. Our struggles are fundamentally unrelatable to many cis people, yet it is essential that cis people look beyond their immediate empathetic reaction for justice. https://t.co/ERx1Xqeuyo
Growth is uncomfortable and must be deliberate. Justice requires that we be willing to be uncomfortable and deliberate to ease the suffering of others.
This is also one of the reasons that relying on empathy alone to determine what is just or who is worth protecting will always reinforce inequality, not challenge it.
Who you immediately empathize with is not "natural"; it's a product of biased socialization and societal prejudices. It must be interrogated and challenged.

Humans are complicated and human relationships are even more complicated.
Whereas true monogamous organisms are bonded to a single partner for life. Many birds are true monogamists, whereas most primates are polygamous. Humans are likely socially monogamous.
Socially monogamous organisms tend to sort themselves into bonded pairs, but change those pairings throughout the lifetime, and sometimes pursue sexual encounters outside of those bonds.
Society makes a lot more sense when you realize that scientifically, we're pretty sure humans are more socially monogamous than truly monogamous.

This grief can feel overwhelming, especially today. I'd like to invite trans people to memorialize people we've lost here.
Allies, listen. Stand with us. Grieve with us. And then fight with us for a world where being trans does not necessitate constant grieving.

This is the legacy of #TransDayOfRemembrance #TDOR 
Grief and loss. But out of that grief and loss, solidarity and togetherness.

Most every trans person knows someone we've lost.
Trans people are fully twice as likely to die in a given year than cis people are.
Trans women in particular are three times as likely to die in a given year as cis women.
For trans women of color the statistics are even grimmer.

This is our biggest holiday - a day in which we can bare our grief to the world. A day in which allies, friends and others can help us to carry it.
Today is a heavy day.

This grief is especially heavy, because trans people often have to carry it themselves.
Officially, trans day of remembrance is a day to honor those who have been murdered. Unofficially, it is a day we remember all trans people who have been lost before their time.

Today is a heavy day. It is heavy with lives cut short and young. It is heavy with the hate that took those lives with it.
It is heavy with grief.

This led to a reactionary shift in what would be considered an "ideal man". The ideal man became stoic, brave, unemotional and detached. He became hardworking, loyal and dutiful beyond all else. He became a prototype for the toxic masculine traits we still see today.

These anxieties and fears of loss of default white masculine supremacy were only exacerbated by the violence of World War I, as millions of young men were drafted and killed and women took a much more independent role in their absence.
In combination with advances in women's rights around the turn of the century, there was anxiety that women's advances would overturn white masculine supremacy.

Truly. The concept of "the ideal man" that a great number of people still aspire to was born directly from concepts of "social Darwinism" and the belief that white American men were becoming "effeminate" and able to be "outcompeted".
We don't discuss nearly enough how contemporary American ideals of masculinity are rooted in reactionary misogyny and particularly white supremacy.

Be critical when consuming information about trans people. Misinformation is rampant. Critically analyze everything you hear about trans people. Was this information written by a cis person? Does it make sense? Is it trying to paint trans people as violent, dangerous or naive?

Educate others. Do your best to spread truthful things about trans people and combat misinformation wherever you can. Remember, trans people are everywhere! Every bit of solidarity and every person who believes in protecting trans lives matters.

Trans people need your help and your protection. 2021 has been the deadliest year on record for trans people. Legislation to make our lives harder has been introduced at record levels in many countries. It is time for allies to step up to protect trans lives. 
So what can you do?
RT @cnlester: 1. What cis people entirely fail to realise is that a large percentage of the world is ALREADY trying to 'convert' #trans peo…
Trans people are not dangerous. We are just regular human beings trying to live our lives in peace, the same as you are.
Trans people don't owe you a disclosure of our transness under any circumstances.

You can't "always tell". Trans people can look like anyone. Every one of us is an individual and plenty of trans people choose to go "stealth", meaning they are not open about being trans. It's very likely you have met a trans person without realizing they are trans.
You don't have to be bi or pan to be attracted to trans people! Trans people are the gender that we say we are, and trans people can look like anyone.
Transphobia is rooted in sexism. Transphobia seeks to confine people into strict gender roles and to limit bodily autonomy. It is feminist to support trans people.

Trans people don't go against biology. Biology is a lot more complicated than what you were taught in grade school, just like we don't teach string theory to high schoolers in physics 1. The overwhelming majority of scientists and doctors support trans people and transition.

Being trans and transitioning are deeply personal experiences. It is not acceptable to ask invasive questions of trans people. If a trans person trusts you with information related to their identity or transition, be honored!

Trans children exist, just as trans adults exist. A person is trans, it's not something that happens to them. Trans children know themselves better than any outsider can, and it's important that we believe them.
Trans people are the experts on our own experiences. We know more about what it is to be trans and what trans people need than cis people, even with the best intentions, ever can.

Trans people deserve to transition in peace. Whether that means socially transitioning (such as presentation, pronouns, names, etc) or medical transition (such as hormones, surgery, etc) trans people aren't asking for "special treatment", and we deserve to be respected.
Being trans is an inherent attribute. We can't be "cured". This also means that people can't be "turned trans", they can just be helped into recognizing their own transness.
Trans people are everywhere. We are estimated to be between 2-5% of the total population. This means you almost definitely know a trans person, whether they're out to you or not.
Firstly, trans people have always been here. We aren't a new phenomena or a "fad", we're just coming under greater scrutiny right now.

Considering the wealth of evidence that shows us that puberty blockers can have immense benefit to transgender and intersex children, including being a lifesaving measure in many cases, these side effects are minimal.

Other miscellaneous effects include delayed growth plate closure, leading to a slightly larger adult height and less development of genital tissue, especially in TPAM, which can limit options for gender affirming surgeries later in life.

Possible effects on bone density have been observed, although the data on this are still unclear, and there is some data that indicates that low bone density may be a previously existing trait of transgender children. https://t.co/U96qQkC4f7

Puberty blockers don't impact fertility in the long term, as when they are stopped, puberty continues normally. What can impact fertility in the long term is HRT. HRT, when administered to TPAM (trans people assigned male at birth), does cause infertility.

Long term, there is much hand-wringing about potential effects on fertility and bone density.
We'll address each of these in turn.

"But what about the side effects?" you would be right to ask. Let's talk about them.
Like all medications, puberty blockers can have side effects. In the short term, possible side effects can include weight gain, hot flashes and headaches.

Many studies, linked below, support the usage of puberty blockers for the treatment of dysphoria on the basis that they are shown to dramatically reduce depression, anxiety, behavioral problems and suicidality and increase self image, life satisfaction and global functioning.

The FDA has approved puberty blockers as a safe and effective form of treatment for precocious puberty. The majority of experts, The Endocrine Society and The World Professional Association for Transgender Health, also support the usage of puberty blockers for treating dysphoria.

In cases of precocious puberty, the medical standard is to administer puberty blockers until the child is the typical age of puberty onset, at which point the child stops blockers and puberty progresses normally. This has been the primary use of puberty blockers for decades.

Puberty blockers were not developed with transgender people in mind. They were developed to treat what is called "precocious puberty", which is a condition some children experience, wherein they experience puberty much earlier than is typical.

The overwhelming majority of peer reviewed evidence shows that children who experience dysphoria will continue to experience dysphoria throughout their lives. We have the medical technology to effectively treat dysphoria, and in children, it starts with puberty blockers.

A slight side note here. There is often discussion in gender critical circles of a phenomena called "desistence". Studies of "desistence" include children who are gender non conforming in many ways, the majority of whom turn out not to be trans, as being trans is uncommon.

At any time during the administration of these medications, the medication can be stopped, and traditional puberty will resume. The vast majority of children who decide to go on puberty blockers will choose to pursue HRT to reduce their dysphoria.

These medications are usually administered in one of two ways, either through a small implant that lasts up to a year (similar to certain forms of hormonal birth control), or through regular injections that can last between one and four months per dosage.

Puberty blockers are most commonly gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, or GnRHs. When taken regularly, these suppress estrogen and testosterone production in the body, allowing these hormones to remain at low levels as they were pre-puberty.

If they decide to proceed with more trans-related healthcare, the child can begin hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and undergo the secondary sex characteristics more aligned with their internal self.
If the child and their loved ones decide that the best option is to continue with traditional puberty, the puberty blockers are stopped, and traditional puberty picks up where it left off.

Puberty blockers allow traditional puberty to be delayed, preventing irreversible secondary sex characteristics from taking hold. This gives the child, and their loved ones, time to evaluate the best options for them going forwards.

When children realize they're trans early enough, we have the medical technology to intervene. But a lot can change for people as young as that. How do we protect children from making irreversible medical decisions too rashly?
The answer is puberty blockers.

This is the reality trans children face. This is the reality every trans adult has faced, and survived.
This is a taste of what dysphoria feels like.
Dysphoria, especially over long periods of time, has dramatic negative effects on mental health and life outcomes.

Cis men, I want you to imagine getting your first period, your chest aching with breast tissue growth. Cis women, I want you to imagine growing facial hair, and your voice deepening. I want you to imagine it viscerally, for as long as you can stand it.

For the cis (not trans) people reading along with me here, I want to propose an exercise. Do your best to remember what puberty felt like. Now I want you to imagine you are developing a different set of secondary sex characteristics than the ones you actually developed.

This temporarily prevents development of certain secondary sex characteristics, such as breast development, voice deepening, facial hair growth, enlargement of the testes and penis, menstrual cycles and more.
"Puberty blockers" themselves are slightly misleadingly named. They don't block all aspects of puberty, just those related to estrogen and testosterone.

To understand puberty blockers, we first must understand what puberty is.
Puberty is the uptick in levels of various hormones in the body that allows for the development of secondary sex characteristics, usually occurring between the ages of 9-15.

Today, let's talk about puberty blockers. What they do, what they don't do, what risks they pose, what risks they alleviate, and more. 🧵
